title: Rustc assumes a type is () sometimes when it should ask for a type annotation
body: I tried this code: ```rust fn print_type(_: &T) { println!("{}", std::any::type_name::()); } fn foo() -> Result { T::generate() } trait MyTrait: Sized { fn generate() -> Result; } impl MyTrait for () { fn generate() -> Result { Ok(()) } } impl MyTrait for i32 { fn generate() -> Result { Ok(0) } } fn indirection() -> Result<&'static str, String> { let x = foo()?; print_type(&x); Ok("abc") } fn main() -> Result<(), String> { let y = foo()?; print_type(&y); indirection()?; Ok(()) } ``` playground: https://play.rust-lang.org/?version=nightly&mode=debug&edition=2021&gist=994a5144bddd3b1e665af930c337bfdf I expected to see this happen: I expected the code to not compile because there is no way to know what type I want for either of the `x` or `y` variables. This should require me to write `let x: ()` in order to compile Instead, this happened: Rust assumes that the type of `x` is `()` and the code compiles and runs. Note that this is somehow related to the use of `?`. Without the `?`, it doesn't compile (as expected), whether the code still uses `Result` or just `T`. Also note that if you remove the `impl MyTrait for ()`, it does not compile and says that `MyTrait is not implemented for ()`: ``` Compiling playground v0.0.1 (/playground) error[[E0277]](https://doc.rust-lang.org/beta/error-index.html#E0277): the trait bound `(): MyTrait` is not satisfied [--> src/main.rs:21:13 ](https://play.rust-lang.org/?version=beta&mode=debug&edition=2021#) | 21 | let x = foo()?; | ^^^ the trait `MyTrait` is not implemented for `()` ``` so it is still assuming that the type is () ### Meta `rustc --version --verbose`: ``` 1.60.0 (stable) 1.62.0-nightly ``` (The above are the versions from the playground)
